markdownRemark.excerpt: Some of the design choices in the blog boilerplate from my earlier post prompted me to look into the the different elements of a Gatsby webpage. However, not…
markdownRemark.html:
Some of the design choices in the blog boilerplate from my earlier post prompted me to look into the the different elements of a Gatsby webpage. However, not knowing Node.js or GraphQL, learning the additional finesses of Gatsby.js has been cumbersome.

Therefore, I have decided to start on the preliminary Gatsby tutorial in order to get a ground-up understanding.

So far, the tutorial haven’t really helped too much, but I was introduced to the static webhosting service called Surge. It is extremely fast and easy to use, and even offers (without SSL-certificate) custom domain names. This is all that is needed to download, create user and deploy. All done in less than a minute. 

 npm install --global surge
 surge login
 gatsby build
 surge public/ solberg.ws
  project: ~/git/blog/public/
   domain: solberg.ws
   upload: [============]
Success! Published and running at solberg.ws

frontmatter.title: Project Blog - Stumbling over Surge
frontmatter.description: Gatsby uses some technologies I'm not familiar with, so I have spent some time learning. In the tutorial, I stumbled over Surge.

frontmatter.title: Project Blog - The unraveling of Gatsby.js
